Awesome coworkers make the biggest difference in the world. I spent today--a professional development day for my district, which means, practically speaking, for those of us who did not take the opportunity to institutionally develop ourselves, a day off--I spent today in the Gorge with one of my fellow language arts teachers, hiking around the beautiful fall waterfalls. It was spectacular, for all the usual reasons: turning leaves, clean air, that amazing silence you get in nature, crisp, sparkling water, nothing but soft under my feet, no one else around... It was also spectacular for all of the intangible reasons that I'm having trouble describing right now. The net effect, though, is that I feel clean, awake, fresh, revitalized--both from the hiking and from the just-cemented-a-new-friendship feeling that comes from spending a day's worth of physical activity and conversation with someone you're just getting to know. I also finished reading Jacob Have I Loved and am well into the sequel to Stargirl. I'm determined to read as much as I possibly can this year, particularly from young adult authors, and I'm feeling pretty good about myself so far. Since school's started, I've read: Stargirl, Loser, Jacob Have I Loved, I've started and put aside The Outsiders, and, in a purely for myself novel, I reread Beloved. Oh, and I read Diary of a Wimpy Kid, but that was mostly cartoons and took like half an hour to finish. Admittedly, young adult novels read fast, but I'm still pretty impressed with myself. Somewhere between four and five books in a little over a month is not too shabby for a crazy-stressed first-year teacher, I think. Maybe one day I'll get back to what I snobbily consider real literature. You know, stuff that you can't read in 15-minute increments at the beginnings of each of your class periods. For now, though, I'm going to catch up on all the books I missed when I was in middle school and all the books that have been written for that age since then. I promised my students that my next book would be from the bulletin board of recommendations that we're developing between all my classes. Unfortunately, none of the books my students have recommended yet seem that interesting to me--but to be fair (I ask them to read stuff they don't want to, after all), I'm going to do it anyway. We'll see how it goes. For now, I'm cheating on them with the Stargirl sequel, but if I finish it this weekend, which I think I will, no one will know anyway:) I'm feeling good.

There is no better way in to the 7th grade psyche than through notes taken from their clenched hands, from half-hidden under their reading books, from the floor when their throwing misfires. 

My favorite pilfered note so far has been this treatise on love and relationships. The first part goes as follows:

"Heyy what do you do when A guy doesn't like u? Do you stop likeing him or do you keep tryin till you think he likes u or does like u?"
"You should still try and like him but if he still does not like you then try and stop."

Great, matter-of-fact advice, right? Keep on trying, but if it doesn't work out you should just stop liking him. If only we all had so much sense! I love a lot of things about this note, but mostly I love how easy it is, and how much sense it makes. There's no "I don't know, it depends on the circumstances, where you are, where he is, etc etc." There's just try a little, and then if it doesn't work, give up.

It seems like that was enough for the first person, too, since the note continues like this:

"OK thanks! Like he talks to me but I think he just doesn't like me! But I'll keep trying a little more but I don't like him that much I just think he's cute!:)"
"OK. I asked DJ out and he said NO!!"
"Woah I thought he liked u though?"
"Me too, but I guess not so anyway I can't wait till pe."

I love this for so many reasons, but that PE bit is my favorite part. Trouble in love? Just go run it off:)

Ah, the seating chart: a total logistical nightmare. It's not enough to simply know that Bryan and Todd need to sit in the front so you can keep an eye on them; you also have to take into account that Bryan can't sit near Breanna because they already had a counseling intervention, can't be too near Jake because they'll never stop talking, and Jake himself also needs to sit in the front but probably needs a cushion of really well-behaved girls around him to keep him in line. Not Julie, though, because she has a crush on him and won't concentrate if she's near him. Sean, who's pretty well behaved otherwise, can't be behind Jake, in the meantime, because that will tempt him to the carefully-aimed spitwad catapulted toward the back of Jake's neck, though it inevitably hits Charlotte, poor Charlotte, who's the sweetest girl ever and who you keep putting by punks as part of that cushion of well-behaved girls. And on it goes. 

Needless to say, after having rearranged my classroom's desk formation this evening, I have spent an inordinate amount of time on seating charts which will, of course, inevitably fail one, two, ten, or even all of my students anyway. heh. At least it's another try though. We'll see how it goes.

In other news, I feel like I've become completely boring. Is this what happens when one joins the work force? One starts thinking of very little apart from one's job? A few days ago (weeks? I don't even know) I was trying to explain my experience of teaching so far, and it basically comes down to the fact that there is no way teaching is an 8-hour-a-day job for me right now. In those 8 hours allotted, let's say six of them are spent actually teaching (with a half hour for a lunch that is somehow never actually a break). Another hour is spent in meetings. So that's seven hours accounted for. The remaining hour, then, is time for me to: plan, grade, call parents, really look at how students are doing, take care of an administrative stuff, either relating to class or to school in general, and do such miscellaneous things as rearrange desks, make seating charts, come up with amazing behavioral incentives like student of the week (which will, of course, have to be thought about and planned), and otherwise take care of everything else that goes into the six hours of teaching and one hour of meetings that will happen tomorrow. 

This is why I am boring. My entire life, currently, has become swallowed by seventh grade. And here I am writing about it more, just in case you were unconvinced that this is really all that I actually think about:)

Oddly enough, I'm feeling pretty good about it right now. It's been a long day, but I got a lot done. And I'm going to get better at this. Just wait.

Yesterday, I woke up way too early, in tears, to haul myself off to a doctor's appointment, then to a planning meeting with the two other seventh grade teachers and our administrator, then over to school to grade a shit-ton of student journals. A working Saturday might have been okay, of course, except that I'd already been at school for a good almost-eleven hours the day before. And it might have been okay except that Friday afternoon--probably six hours into my 11-hour stint--had been quite possibly the worst afternoon yet of my two weeks of teaching. I'd biked home thinking there was no way I was every going to be able to do this, and I woke up not to a badly-needed weekend but to more planning, more grading, more school, more reminder that I'm signing my life away to seventh graders. 

So what does this have to do with being lucky? 

It comes from people. From James holding me on Saturday morning, letting me cry, and reminding me that I can do this. From the other two 7th-grade teachers, also new, who are just as crazy as me right now and just as adamant that we're going to do things right. From my vice principal, who gave up her Saturday to help us out. From my new roommate, whose crazy social-work job reminds me that there's a reason I'm trying to help even the punkiest of 7th-grade punks get an education and understand that their actions have consequences. 

My luck comes from BJ and Aimee, two too-long-neglected friends, calling to say hi and invite me to a game night. From seeing BJ biking the other direction and waving wildly across the street to him, huge grin breaking out across both of our faces. From my brother, who's doing his first triathlon today and whose phone call yesterday salvaged my afternoon. From the man at the farmer's market who perpetually asks "like poetry?" and who gave me a poem today when I said that yes, indeed I do. From those of you, near and far, who check in with me every once in a while and let me know I'm still in your thoughts. 

Thank you, thank you, thank you. Despite the crazy of my last two weeks, you make me the luckiest stasia in the world.
